IN THE COURT OF THE JUDICIAL I CLASS MAGISTRATE-V,
(SPECIAL COURT FOR MARK LIST CASES), THIRUVANANTHAPURAM.
Present:- Smt. Aswathy.S, Judicial First Class Magistrate-V,
Thiruvananthapuram.
Thursday the 23" day of January, 2025./ 3 Magha, 1946.
CCG. 197/2010
Complainant : State represented by the Sub Inspector of Police, Thampanoor
Police Station in Crime No. 219/97.
(By Assistant Public Prosecutor )
Accused : A5. Ajith, aged 49 years, S/o. Natarajan, TC. 21/1057,
Near Thycaud Hospital, Thycaud Village.
(By Advocate Sri. Panayam Shaji.S)
Charge : Offences punishable under sections 143, 147, 148, 149, 427 and
506(ii) of Indian Penal Code, 1860.
Plea : Not guilty
Finding : Not guilty
Sentence : Accused No.5 is found not guilty of offences punishable under
sections 143, 147, 148, 149, 427 and 506(ii) of Indian Penal
Code, 1860 and he is acquitted of the said offences under section
248(1) Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973. His bail bond stand
cancelled and he is set at liberty.
Description of accused

10.12.2024 21.01.2025 23.01.2025
This case having been finally heard on today the court on the same day delivered the
following :-
JUDGMENT

1. Accused stands trial for offences punishable under sections 143, 147, 148, 149,
427 and 506(ii) of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

2. The prosecution case in brief is as follows :- On 14.09.1997, at about 9.00
pm, accused persons blocked an autorickshaw bearing No. KL-01-K-1679
which was owned by CW1, at the lane near Thampanoor Bus Stand. Accused
No.1 had broken the wind screen glass of the vehicle by hitting it with an iron
rod. Accused No.2 intimidated that CW1 could be killed. Accused Nos. 3 and
4 pulled out CW1 and CW2 from the autorickshaw. Thereafter, they smashed
the side glass of the autorickshaw by hitting it with an iron rod. Owing to these
risks of mischief CW1 sustained financial loss of Rs. 1500/-. Immediately
after the incident CW1 rushed to the police station and lodged the complaint.
Thus the accused persons have committed offences punishable under
sections 143, 147, 148, 149, 427 and 506(ii) of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

3. Final report was filed by the Sub Inspector of police, Additional Chief Judicial
Magistrate Court, Thiruvananthapuram and the case was taken on file as

3 of 8

C.C.26/1998. Cognizance was taken for the offences punishable u/s. 143, 147,
148, 149, 427 and 506(ii) of Indian Penal Code, 1860 against the accused Nos.
1 to 5. Subsequently accused Nos. 1, 2 and 4 are acquitted in that court as per
judgment in CC. 26/98 dated 30.09.2004. Case against accused Nos. 3 and 5 is
split up and refiled as CC. 1135/2004. Thereafter, it was transferred to this
court, in pursuance of the order of the Hon'ble Chief Judicial Magistrate,
Thiruvananthapuram, the case was refiled as CC. 139/2008. Subsequently
accused No.3 is acquitted as per judgment in CC. 139/2008 dated 23.06.2010.
Case against accused Nos. 5 is split up and refiled as CC. 70/2010. He was
absconding and therefore the case against him transferred to the Register of
Long Pending cases as LP.08/11. On 22.03.2024 Accused No.5 was present
before this court and the case was refiled as CC.197/2010.

4. On appearance of the accused No.5, he was enlarged on bail on 22.03.2024.
Copies of all relevant prosecution records were furnished to him under section
207 Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973. After hearing prosecution and counsel
for accused No.5 charge framed for offences u/ss. 143, 147, 148, 149, 427 and
506(ii) of Indian Penal Code, 1860, read over and explained to the accused
No.5 to which he pleaded not guilty and claimed to be tried.

4of8

5. On the side of prosecution, PW1 to PW3 were examined, Exhibits P1 to P4
were marked.

6. On completion of the prosecution evidence, the accused No.5 was examined
under section 313(1)(b) Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973., during which he
denied all the incriminating circumstances appearing in the prosecution
evidence against him and added that he is innocent of the allegations levelled
against him. Thereafter the case was posted for defence evidence. No defence
evidence was adduced from the side of the accused No.5.

7. Heard both sides and perused records.

8. The following points have arisen for determination:

1. Whether accused Nos. 1 to 5 were formed an unlawful assembly in
prosecution of their common object, and accused No.5 became a member of
that assembly, on 14.09.1997, at about 9.00 pm, at the lane near
Thampanoor Bus Stand and thereby committed an offence u/s.143 of Indian
Penal Code 1860 ?

2. Whether on the same day at the same time and place, accused No.5 in
prosecution of their common object, committed the offence of rioting along
with accused Nos. 1 to 4 and have thereby committed offence punishable
under section 147 read with 149 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 ?

5 of 8

3. Whether on the same day at same time and place, accused No.5 in
prosecution of their common object, armed with deadly weapons, along
with accused Nos. 1 to 4 and have thereby committed offence punishable
under section 148 read with 149 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 ?

4, Whether on the same day at same time and place, in prosecution of their
common object of accused Nos. 1 to 5, accused Nos. 3 and 4 smashed the
side glass of the autorickshaw by hitting with an iron rod thereby CW1
sustained financial loss of Rs. 1500/- and accused No.5 being a member of
that assembly thereby committed offence punishable under section 427 r/w.
149 of Indian Penal Code, 1860?

5. Whether on the same day at same time and place, in prosecution of their
common object of accused Nos. 1 to 5, accused No.2 intimidated that CW1
could be killed and accused No.5 being a member of that assembly thereby
committed offence punishable under section 506 (ii) r/w. 149 of Indian
Penal Code, 1860?

6. If the accused is found guilty? What is the order of the sentence?

9, Point Nos. 1 to 5 :-To avoid repetition and for brevity, point numbers 1 to 5 are
considered together. Prosecution case is that the accused has committed
offences punishable under sections 143, 147, 148, 149, 341, 427 and 506(ii) of
Indian Penal Code, 1860.

10. Evidence adduced by the prosecution:- PW1 S.Suresh Kumar had conducted
the investigation of the above case .He deposed that he had prepared the Ext P1

6 of 8

scene mahasar cum vehicle mahasar and subsequently the vehicle was released
to the interim custody of CW1 as per Ext 2 receipt _He further admitted the
report as to the identity of the accused persons which was marked as Ext P3 .

11.PW2 Abdul Rashi was filed the final report before the court .PW3 Sanal
Kumar was GD in charge on the alleged day of incident in Thampanoor police
station .He deposed that asper the statement given by CW1 he registered Ext
P4 FIR .In his cross examination he deposed that the FIR was registered on the
next day after the incident and the identity of the accused persons were not
stated .

12.Submission made by learned counsel for the accused:- The learned counsel
submitted that the person who sustained loss had not been examined by the
prosecution, hence accused is entitled to get acquittal.

13.Submission_made_ by learned Assistant Public_Prosecutor:- The learned
Assistant Public Prosecutor submitted that the evidence of PW1 to PW3 are
sufficient to prove the guilt of the accused persons. The leamed Assistant
Public Prosecutor had given up other witnesses and he is justified in doing so

7 of 8

since it is reported that the presence of the material witnesses cannot be
procured in the near future .

14.Evaluation of evidence: - In order to fasten the liability of accused no.5, the
prosecution has to prove that the accused no.5 was also a member of unlawful
assembly and he committed mishief in prosecution of common object of that
assembly. The person who had sustained the loss there is no occular witness.
had not been examined by the prosecution. On analysis of the evidence of
prosecution it can be seen that there is no direct evidence to prove that the
accused has committed the offence as alleged by the prosecution .Having
considered evidence on record, this court is of the view that prosecution has
failed to prove the guilt of the accused. For the said reason these points are
found against the prosecution.

15.Point No. 6 :- Upon the finding in point nos. 1 to 5, the accused No.5 is found
not guilty of offences punishable under sections 143, 147, 148, 149, 427 and
506(ii) of Indian Penal Code, 1860 and he is acquitted for the said offences
under section 248(1) Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973. His bail bond stand
cancelled and he is set at liberty.

8 of 8
No material objects produced in this case.
Dictated to the Confidential Assistant, transcribed and typed by her, corrected by me
and pronounced in the open court on this the 23‚Äù day of January, 2025.
Sd/-
Judicial First Class Magistrate-V,
Thiruvananthapuram.
